Award.AwardTitle: Scaling-up the Introductory Undergraduate STEM Courses at Berea College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This WIDER project is transforming the introductory STEM courses at Berea College into high-­engagement, active learning environments following the SCALE-­UP model that has shown to be successful in physics and other STEM disciplines. Introductory courses in biology, chemistry, physics, and computer science are being targeted. Baseline data described the enrollments and instructional modes in the targeted courses. These courses are being further enhanced by the inclusion of undergraduate Teaching Associates from the Berea College Labor Program (work study), who are acting as peer instructors in the classroom and enabling the program to maintain a student-­teacher ratio of 10-1 that is supporting student learning.

The underlying change strategy for this project can be described as environmental/emergent. It is capitalizing on a faculty culture of reflective teaching, while moving towards a shared vision for first year STEM courses. This project is creating lasting, transformative change by: 1) supporting a faculty-­led initiative to implement substantive changes in introductory STEM classrooms, 2) by deepening knowledge about evidence-­based practice among the faculty, and by 3)improving student learning and retention in first year STEM courses.

This project capitalizes on several strengths of Berea College, including its well­-established Labor Program, a collegial and collaborative environment for teaching, and the faculty's commitment to providing a high-­quality education to underserved students from Appalachia and beyond. Because of its historic mission to serve groups traditionally under-­represented in higher education and STEM, Berea College is ideally placed to gauge the effectiveness of this model on the retention and success of economically disadvantaged students in STEM disciplines. In addition, as a member of the Work Colleges Consortium, Berea is serving as a national exemplar for the implementation of studio-­based introductory STEM courses using undergraduate Teaching Associates to maintain a low student-­teacher ratio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Berea College is a four-year, liberal arts institution in Eastern Kentucky, dedicated to providing an educational opportunity for students, primarily from Appalachia, who show great academic promise but have limited economic resources. This NSF-funded WIDER project supported the implementation of a professional development program that supported faculty adoption of evidence-based teaching and learning practices in the introductory STEM classroom. Courses in biology, chemistry, computer science, mathematics, and physics were targeted. The implementation of this faculty development program was particularly timely, as the College began construction of the Margaret A. Cargill Natural Sciences and Health Building, designated to open in the Fall of 2018.

We developed a two-stage faculty development model that combined a four-day course redesign workshop at the end of the spring semester, with on-going participation in a faculty learning community (FLC) during the following academic year. During summer workshops participants were exposed to learner-centered pedagogies while redesigning the syllabus for a course they intended to teach the following academic year. Workshop themes included motivation, significant learning goals and objectives, learner-centered assessment, major non-traditional assignments, and objective-assignment alignment. Participants represented all five STEM disciplines at the College and include a broad mix of instructors, as well as both pre- and post-tenure faculty members. A significant fraction (more than two-thirds) of faculty who teach in the first-year STEM curriculum participated in one of three course transformation workshops during the three-year period of the WIDER grant. Participation was robust in all disciplines except biology, which had just under a forty-percent participation rate. Several faculty participated in more than one workshop.

Faculty Learning Communities (FLCs) met during the academic year to support the work of faculty in transforming their courses. Faculty met twice monthly to discuss active-learning pedagogies, classroom management strategies, and challenges related to shifting pedagogical approaches. Topics for readings and discussions included the design and implementation of studio-based courses, developing probing questions and Socratic dialogs, how to design effective collaborative instruction, and using written assignments to enhance understanding.

In order to assess the effectiveness of the faculty development model, classroom observations and faculty interviews were conducted during the first two years of the grant. Twelve participating faculty members and eight from a control group of non-participants were observed and interviewed over the course of four semesters. Preliminary analysis of the observations indicates a strong correlation between faculty beliefs about the nature of teaching and learning (epistemological beliefs) and classroom practice, perhaps not surprisingly. Participants in the faculty development group had higher epistemological beliefs and engaged in more student-centered teaching compared to non-participants, although this cannot be attributed entirely to the current faculty development project.  However, it does suggest that effective faculty development should target the epistemology of teaching in addition to specific pedagogies.

Significant curricular outcomes of this project include the development of an Arduino-based curriculum for the introductory physics lab, as well as the development of new collaborative learning activities for introductory biology and organic chemistry. Due to the high rate of participation among faculty, the number of curricular transformations in development,  and the opportunities posed through the innovative learning spaces in the new Cargill science building, we believe this project has resulted in lasting transformation of the STEM curriculum at Berea College.
